column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Faithful 's plain dealing with Talkative

#Text=They say , you are a spot among Christians ; and that religion fareth the worse for your ungodly conversation ; that some have already stumbled at your wicked ways , and that more are in danger of being destroyed thereby ; your religion , and an ale-house , and covetousness , and uncleanness , and swearing , and lying , and vain-company keeping , &c . , will stand together .
#Text=The proverb is true of you which is said of a whore , to wit , that she is a shame to all women ; so are you a shame to all professors .
#Text=TALK .
#Text=Since you are ready to take up reports and to judge so rashly as you do , I cannot but conclude you are some peevish or melancholy man , not fit to be discoursed with ; and so adieu .
#Text=CHR .
#Text=Then came up Christian , and said to his brother , I told you how it would happen : your words and his lusts could not agree ; he had rather leave your company than reform his life .

#Text=But he is gone , as I said ; let him go , the loss is no man 's but his own ; he has saved us the trouble of going from him ; for he continuing ( as I suppose he will do ) as he is , he would have been but a blot in our company :
#Text=besides , the apostle says , " From such withdraw thyself . "
#Text=FAITH .
#Text=But I am glad we had this little discourse with him ; it may happen that he will think of it again :
#Text=however , I have dealt plainly with him , and so am clear of his blood , if he perisheth .
#Text=CHR .

#Text=You did well to talk so plainly to him as you did ; there is but little of this faithful dealing with men now-a-days , and that makes religion to stink so in the nostrils of many , as it doth ; for they are these talkative fools whose religion is only in word , and are debauched and vain in their conversation , that ( being so much admitted into the fellowship of the godly ) do puzzle the world , blemish Christianity , and grieve the sincere .
#Text=I wish that all men would deal with such as you have done : then should they either be made more conformable to religion , or the company of saints would be too hot for them .
#Text=Then did Faithful say ,
#Text=How Talkative at first lifts up his plumes !
#Text=How bravely doth he speak !
#Text=How he presumes To drive down all before him !
#Text=But so soon As Faithful talks of heart-work , like the moon That 's past the full , into the wane he goes .
#Text=And so will all , but he that HEART-WORK knows .
#Text=Thus they went on talking of what they had seen by the way , and so made that way easy which would otherwise , no doubt , have been tedious to them ; for now they went through a wilderness .
#Text=Now , when they were got almost quite out of this wilderness , Faithful chanced to cast his eye back , and espied one coming after them , and he knew him .
#Text=Oh ! said Faithful to his brother , who comes yonder ?
#Text=Then Christian looked , and said , It is my good friend Evangelist .
#Text=Ay , and my good friend too , said Faithful , for it was he that set me in the way to the gate .
#Text=Now was Evangelist come up to them , and thus saluted them :
#Text=EVAN .
#Text=Peace be with you , dearly beloved ; and peace be to your helpers .
#Text=CHR .
#Text=Welcome , welcome , my good Evangelist , the sight of thy countenance brings to my remembrance thy ancient kindness and unwearied labouring for my eternal good .
#Text=FAITH .
#Text=And a thousand times welcome , said good Faithful .
#Text=Thy company , O sweet Evangelist , how desirable it is to us poor pilgrims !
#Text=EVAN .
#Text=Then said Evangelist , How hath it fared with you , my friends , since the time of our last parting ?
#Text=What have you met with , and how have you behaved yourselves ?
#Text=Then Christian and Faithful told him of all things that had happened to them in the way ; and how , and with what difficulty , they had arrived at that place .
#Text=EVAN .

#Text=Right glad am I , said Evangelist , not that you have met with trials , but that you have been victors ; and for that you have , notwithstanding many weaknesses , continued in the way to this very day .
#Text=I say , right glad am I of this thing , and that for mine own sake and yours .

#Text=I have sowed , and you have reaped : and the day is coming , when both he that sowed and they that reaped shall rejoice together ; that is , if you hold out : " for in due season ye shall reap , if ye faint not . "
#Text=[ John 4:36 , Gal . 6:9 ]
#Text=The crown is before you , and it is an incorruptible one ; so run , that you may obtain it . [ 1 Cor . 9:24-27 ]

#Text=Some there be that set out for this crown , and , after they have gone far for it , another comes in , and takes it from them : hold fast , therefore , that you have ; let no man take your crown .
#Text=[ Rev. 3:11 ]

#Text=You are not yet out of the gun-shot of the devil ; you have not resisted unto blood , striving against sin ; let the kingdom be always before you , and believe steadfastly concerning things that are invisible .

#Text=Let nothing that is on this side the other world get within you ; and , above all , look well to your own hearts , and to the lusts thereof , " for they are deceitful above all things , and desperately wicked " ; set your faces like a flint ; you have all power in heaven and earth on your side .
